docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM: You lose most of your body heat through your head. THE FACTS: Put on a hat, parents tell their children before sending them outside on bitter winter days. While that might be sound advice, the popular belief behind it -- that most of the body's heat escapes through the head -- is misguided. The amount of heat released by any part of the body depends largely on its surface area, and on a cold day you would lose more heat through an exposed leg or arm than a bare head.
docs.abstract: Individuals do not lose majority of heat through head; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: While "put on a hat" might be sound advice, the popular belief behind it is misguided.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 5:30 in the morning. I noticed an elderly man being whizzed into the emergency department on a stretcher. What was unusual were his movements. He seemed to occupy a fourth dimension, oscillating in several directions at the same time. The year was 1956, and I was a fledgling intern, working in the emergency room at a hospital in New York, trying to survive the 8 p.m. to 8 a.m. shift.

headline.main: Nurse, Where Do We Keep the Chicken Wire and Lamp Cord?

docs.abstract: Dr Larry Zaroff Cases column describes treating emergency patient in 1956 and using make-shift internal pacemaker hookup constructed using items purchased at local hardware store; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Desperate for a solution, a doctor tries the hardware store when hospital equipment won't do.

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents want their children to succeed. And these days, toy store shelves are filled with products with names like Baby Einstein and Brainy Baby. The toy manufacturers do not come out and say it, but the clear implication is that babies who play with these toys may score some extra I.Q. points and get an early start on the road to an Ivy League college.

headline.main: The Problem With Some 'Smart' Toys: (Hint) Use Your Imagination

docs.abstract: Child development experts question growing trend of toy manufacturers to produce toys they claim stimulate early childhood development and learning; Dr Kathleen Kiely Gouley, New York University Child Study Center psychiatry assistant professor, asserts that although some toys are highly entertaining, they may make child more of passive observer rather than participant; no studies have linked increased intelligence to playing with certain toys or videos, despite packaging claims that say they do; Dr Kathy Hirsh-Pasek, Temple University psychology professor and author of Einstein Never Used Flash Cards: How Our Children Really Learn, suggests that toys that emphasize memorization do not allow child to learn problem-solving and creative thinking; photo (L)
docs.snippet: No studies exist to show that toys or videos designed to give children an intellectual edge over playmates do so.

docs.lead_paragraph: If gridlock, stress and delays were not enough, scientists have found another reason for people to dread their daily commute. Sitting in traffic nearly triples the risk of suffering a heart attack a short time later, according to a study published last week. The heightened risk, which applies to drivers, bicyclists and people using public transportation, may be a result of exposure to airborne pollutants that inflame the lungs and damage arteries, but the emotional stress of trudging through traffic could also be a factor, the researchers said.

headline.main: Heart Attack Risk Linked To Time Spent in Traffic

docs.abstract: Dr Annette Peters, GSF-National Research Center for Environment and Health, Germany, epidemiologist, leads study on link between heart attacks and commuting; study, published in New England Journal of Medicine, finds that even one hour in traffic increases likelihood of heart attack almost three times normal rate; stress and particulate matter in air are suggested causes of increased risk (M)
docs.snippet: Sitting in traffic nearly triples the risk of suffering a heart attack a short time later, according to a study published last week.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GSF-NATIONAL RESEARCH CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENT AND HEALTH

docs.lead_paragraph: This is head-injury time for school athletes. With football, soccer, hockey and basketball, more players than not are likely to fall or be hit on the head, and many will be hit hard enough to get concussions. Studies have found that each season as many as one high school football player in five suffers concussions, a violent jarring of the brain against the unyielding skull. And many of those injuries will be mishandled, with the players allowed to return to the game before their brains have recovered, placing them at risk for a second hit that could have far more severe consequences.

headline.main: In Sports, Play Smart and Watch Your Head

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes different levels of concussive injuries and proper medical treatment and protocol for student athletes who suffer concussions; stresses importance of time off from play that could cause second-impact damage to young, developing brain; symptoms of serious concussion-related problems discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Head injuries result in more sports-related deaths in this country than any other athletic injury.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nursing mothers, especially those who go back to work, often pump their breast milk so that their babies can drink it from a bottle. A new study suggests, however, that if the milk is chilled for too long, it may lose some of its health benefits. Writing in The Archives of Childhood Disease, researchers said the antioxidants in breast milk that had been refrigerated were less active than those in fresh breast milk. Milk that had been frozen showed even less activity, the study said. The researchers stressed, however, that the implications of the findings were not clear.
docs.abstract: Dr Thomas Hegyi of Robert Wood Johnson Medical School leads study that shows breast milk loses some of its antioxidant strength when refrigerated and loses even more when frozen; study, published in Archives of Childhood Disease, does not suggest women stop breast feeding; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that if mother's milk is chilled for too long, it may lose some of its health benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early life stresses may lead to lifelong behavioral problems, but a change in the environment can help if it comes early enough. The study, by researchers at the Oregon Health & Science University's primate research center and the University of Pittsburgh, looked at what happened when baby monkeys were separated from their mothers.
docs.abstract: University of Pittsburgh and Oregon Health and Science University primate research center scientists conduct study on effects of separation stress on young monkeys; study, presented at Society for Neuroscience conference, finds that monkeys separated from their mothers fared much better emotionally when placed quickly with surrogate (S)
docs.snippet: Early life stresses may lead to lifelong behavioral problems, but a change in the environment can help if it comes early enough.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pull up your cheeks and you may briefly remove some years from that reflection in the mirror. But is it accurate to blame the forces of gravity for the havoc that aging wreaks on youthful features? Probably not. A new study suggests that gravity's role in aging has been exaggerated, and that the downward migration of facial skin over time is merely an illusion. The real culprit, the study found, is the loss of volume underneath the skin.

headline.main: In Case of the Falling Face, Gravity Is Acquitted

docs.abstract: Dr Val Lambros, California-based plastic surgeon, conducts study that suggests gravity is not primary culprit in aging faces and instead cites loss of volume underneath skin as cause; study, presented at American Society of Plastic Surgeons conference, is based on photographs taken of individuals over time; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that gravity's role in facial aging has been exaggerated and that the real culprit is the loss of volume underneath the skin.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people breathe easier as they get ready to leave the office at the end of the workday. But there may be more to it than just getting out of the pressure cooker. Breathing really does seem to become easier in the late afternoon, report researchers who were looking at circadian rhythms' effects on the lungs.

headline.main: Lungs May Have a Body Check

docs.abstract: Dr Boris I Medarov of Long Island Jewish Medical Center leads study that finds lung function changes throughout day, with easiest breathing during late-afternoon and most difficult breathing around noon; study, presented at American College of Chest Physicians conference, suggests that doctors remove breathing tubes from patients late in day to maximize patient's breathing capacity; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Breathing does seem to become easier in the late afternoon, report researchers who were looking at circadian rhythms' effects on the lungs.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''This is the train to Hiroshima,'' the conductor announced. I was not planning to go there. I was heading instead to Kyoto. But the 59th anniversary of the first atomic bomb attack had just passed, and the third anniversary of my sister's death at the World Trade Center in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was approaching in a few weeks. In New York, there was controversy over what kind of memorial should be built downtown, and what the planned Museum of Freedom would or should contain. I wondered how the Japanese had commemorated the victims of an even deadlier attack. I decided to take the train to the original ground zero.

headline.main: A Timely Lesson in Horror Unvarnished

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman commentary on visiting Japan's memorial complex for victims of World War II atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki; contends that memorial to Sept 11 attack on former World Trade Center site might include similar harsh and shocking items, even if they make visitors feel uncomfortable (S)
docs.snippet: Should New York take a cue from the original ground zero?
